introduction.p:
Recall that work by constant force is indepndent of the path of motion but simply the dot product of the force \vec F and the displacement \Delta \vec r.
W_{if} = \vec F\, \cdot\, \Delta \vec r\ \ \ (\text{case of constant force})

Writing \Delta \vec r as the difference of the positions
\Delta \vec r = \vec r_f - \vec r_i
this work can be written as a difference of two quantities, one evaluated at each end of the motion.
W_{if} = \vec F\, \cdot\, \vec r_f - \vec F\, \cdot\, \vec r_i\ \ \ (\text{case of constant force})

This form of work is not restricted to only constant forces. The same happens to several other forces, e.g., Newton's gravitational force, spring force, and electric force, which are not constant, but depend on the position. These forces are called conservative forces .

Evaluating the work integrals in the case of weight, spring force, Newton's gravitational force, and Coulomb's electric force give the following results.
\amp W_{if} = mgy_i - mgy_f\ \ \ (\text{Weight}) \amp W_{if} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx_i^2 - \dfrac{1}{2}kx_f^2\ \ \ (\text{Spring}) \amp W_{if} = \left( -\dfrac{Gm_1m_2}{r_i} \right) - \left( -\dfrac{Gm_1m_2}{r_f} \right)\ \ \ (\text{Newton's gravitation}) \amp W_{if} = \left( \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q_1q_2}{r_i} \right) - \left( \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q_1q_2}{r_f} \right)\ \ \ (\text{Coulomb's electric force})
The derivation of the first three are presented below. Each case can be formally written as a difference of two terms, one evaluated at t_i and the other at t_f.

Thus, for every conservative force we can write the work done as the potential energy at the initial instant minus the potential energy at the final instant.
W_{if}^{\text{conservative}} = U_i - U_f,
where U takes different form for different forces. We also write this as
W_{if}^{\text{conservative}} = - \Delta U,
where \Delta U = U_f - U_i .

subsection.title: Work by weight - Calculus
subsection.p: Weight is a conservative force. Since weight is a constant force, work done by weight will be independent of path as shown before.

Consider an object of mass m . We wish to find the work done by the weight between instants t_i , when the block is at coordinate (x_i, y_i, z_i) , and t_f , when the block is at coordinate (x_f, y_f, z_f) .

Let positive y axis be pointed up, then, weight vector is
\vec W = - mg \hat j,
where \hat j is the unit vector pointed in the direction of the positive y axis. A general formula for the displacement vector is
d\vec r = \hat i\, dx + \hat j\, dy + \hat k\, dz,
where as usual \hat i and \hat k are unit vectors in the positive x and z directions respectively. Therefore, the integral that gives the work done by weight during interval.
W_{if} = \int_i^f\, \vec W \cdot d\vec r = \int_{y_i}^{y_f}\, (- mg) dy = m\, g\, y_i - m\, g\, y_f,
which is independent of the path and only depends upon the coordinates of the initial and final positions alogn with some constants.

subsection.title: Work by spring force - Calculus
subsection.p: As an example of a conservative force, we will find the work done by a spring force on a block.

sidebyside.p: Let a spring of spring constant k be along the x axis with origin at the position of the block when the spring is not stretched and the positive x axis is in the direction that leads to the stretching of the spring.

subsection.p: We wish to find the work done by the spring force between instants t_i , when the block is at coordinate x_i , and t_f , when the block is at coordinate x_f .

Let x be the coordinate of the block at instant t . The work is given by the integral
W_{if} = \int_i^f\, \vec F \cdot d\vec r = \int_{x_i}^{x_f}\, (- k x ) dx = \frac{1}{2} k x_i^2 - \frac{1}{2} k x_f^2,
which is independent of the path between x_i and x_f since we will get the same integral whether motion has no full oscillations between t_i and t_f or had multiple oscillations.
